div1.head: Military Orders regarding yellow fever damages, July 21, 1900
div1.p:

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES Vol 179 B 1900

Adjutant General's
OFFICE
AUG. 8, 1900
NOTED: RETURNS
ROLLS DIVISION.

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF HAVANA
AND PINAR DEL RIO.

SPECIAL ORDERS,
No. 65. }

Acting Assistant Surgeon P. Conover Field. U. S. Army;
will assemble at these headquarters, at such times as may be
necessary, at the call of the president thereof, for the pur-
pose of examining into and reporting upon such claims as
may be referred to it from these headquarters for compen-
sation for damage done to personal property through disin-
fection or destruction, necessary to prevent the spread of
yellow fever.
Report will be made upon each case separately.
2. A board of officers, to consist of:

is appointed to meet from time to time, at the call of the
president thereof, to examine into and report upon such
claims as may be referred to it from these headquarters for
compensation for alleged use or occupation of, or injury
done to private property by United States troops.
Report will be made upon each case separately.

3. Private James Sheedy, Company L, 1st Infantry, hav-
ing been tried by a general court-martial convened at Gua-
najay Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of sleeping on post,
in violation of the 39th Article of War (six previous con-
victions), was sentenced “To be dishonorably discharged the
service of the United States, forfeiting all pay and allowances now
due, or which may become due, and to be confined at hard labor,
at such place as the reviewing authority may designate, for the
period of six (6) months.”

The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed, un-
til further orders, at Guanajay Barracks, Cuba.

4. Major Walter Reed, Surgeon, U. S. Army, will proceed
to Pinar del Rio Barracks, Cuba, for the purpose of inves-
tigating and reporting upon certain yellow fever cases re-
ported as having occurred at that post. Upon completion
of this duty Major Reed will return to Columbia Barracks,
Cuba.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

5. Upon the recommendation of the Acting Chief Sur-
geon, the following named contract nurses will be fur-
nished, by the Quartermaster's Department, transportation
from Columbia Barracks to Pinar del Rio Barracks, to
which place they are ordered for temporary duty.

Alice M. Gillette, Minnie Cooke, Ella M. Gillen, Kate S.
M. Ledlie.

6. Upon the recommendation of the Acting Chief Sur-
geon, Acting Hospital Steward George S. Spurlin, U. S.
Army, and one private of the Hospital Corps, detailed for
duty at the Non-Immune Camp, near Quemados, Cuba, per
paragraph 6, Special Orders No. 30, c. s., these headquar-
ters, are hereby relieved, to date from July 18, 1900, and
are assigned to Columbia Barracks for duty.

7. Upon the recommendation of the Acting Chief Sur-
geon, Acting Assistant Surgeon Raoul A. Amador, U. S.
Army, having been assigned for duty in this Department,
will proceed to Pinar del Rio Barracks and report to the
Commanding Officer of that post.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

8. Complying with instructions contained in an endorse-
ment dated Headquarters Division of Cuba, July 18, 1900,
a board of survey, to consist of:

will convene at the Medical Supply Depot. Havana, on
Monday, the 23d instant, or as soon thereafter as practica-
ble, for the purpose of reporting upon and submitting rec-
ommendation regarding the disposition that should be
made of some twelve or thirteen hundred iron bedsteads
with woven wire mattresses, stored at that Depot, and re-
ported by Major M. C. Wyeth, Surgeon, U. S. Army, as un-
satisfactory.

9. Complying with instructions contained in an endorse-
ment dated Headquarters Division of Cuba, July 19, 1900,
a board of survey, to consist of:

will convene at the Principe Quartermaster's Depot, Ha-
vana, on Monday, the 23d instant, or as soon thereafter as
practicable, to examine into, report upon and fix the re-
sponsibility for the damaged condition found in certain
cases of clothing on hand at that Depot, and for which
Major Chauncey B. Baker, Quartermaster, U. S. Volun-
teers, Depot Quartermaster, reports himself accountable.

10. Complying with instructions contained in an endorse-
ment dated Headquarters Division of Cuba, July 19, 1900,
a board of survey, to consist of:

will convene at the Principe Quartermaster's Depot, Ha-
vana, on Monday, the 23d instant, or as soon thereafter as
practicable, for the purpose of investigating and reporting
upon the cause of damage to certain quantities of bed-sacks,
mosquito bars, and shelter tent halves, the property of the
United States, for which Major Chauncey B. Baker, Quar-
termaster, U. S. Volunteers, Depot Quartermaster, reports
himself accountable.

The board will also submit recommendation as to the
disposition that should be made of this property.

11. Under the provisions of A. R. 1272, the Subsistence
Department will commute the rations of Private Joseph
Rosenblatt, Troop M, 7th Cavalry, on duty in the office of
the Post Commissary, Columbia Barracks, from and includ-
ing July 16, 1900, and whilst he is engaged on said duty, at
the rate of seventy-five (75) cents per day, it being im-
practicable to provide for his subsistence in any other way.

12. Upon the recommendation of the Acting Chief Sur-
geon of the Department, the Quartermaster's Department
will ship to the Surgeon, Pinar del Rio Barracks, Cuba, the
following named articles:

One (1) Bi-chloride spray pump.
One (1) Formaldehyde Generator.
One (1) Carboy of Formalin.
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL LEE:

R. E. L. MICHIE,
Assistant Adjutant General.
